articles.author: Condé Nast

articles.title: The Pitchfork Review: All of the Latest Episodes
articles.content:
---
title: The Pitchfork Review: All of the Latest Episodes
author: Condé Nast
url: https://pitchfork.com/podcast/the-pitchfork-review/
hostname: pitchfork.com
description: Listen to every episode of Pitchfork’s podcast for music fans and obsessives.
sitename: Pitchfork
date: 2024-01-11
tags: ['web']
---
Brought to you by the music critics at Pitchfork, The Pitchfork Review is a show for music fans and obsessives who can’t wait to talk about the latest releases. Co-hosted by Pitchfork editor-in-chief Puja Patel and Reviews Editor Jeremy D. Larson, this podcast pulls back the curtain on our reviews and scores, dives deep into new music, and gives an expert guide to what’s exciting, what’s great, and what’s just plain terrible.
Listen to every episode of Pitchfork’s podcast for music fans and obsessives.
Related Articles
The Origins and Influence of Brian Eno’s Pioneering Album Ambient 1: Music for Airports
In the latest episode of Pitchfork’s podcast, our critics revisit the legendary producer’s classic 1978 LP, which was recently featured in our Sunday Review series.
By Pitchfork
Jeff Tweedy on Rock Criticism, the Pitfalls of Music Snobbery, and His New Book
The musician and author discusses World Within a Song, in which he writes about 50 songs that rearranged his brain, Wilco’s new album, and more.
By Pitchfork
The 2023 Music Grab Bag: Trends, Scandals, and Theories
In this episode of the Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics talk about the rise of the musical theater girlie, the fall of the 1975’s Matty Healy, and more. Plus: Alvvays’ Molly Rankin reveals the song she wishes she wrote.
By Pitchfork
The Best, Worst, and Most Surprising Albums of 2023
In this episode of The Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics talk about some of their faves from our 50 Best Albums of 2023 list and lament a few of the year’s biggest disappointments.
By Pitchfork
Why the Replacements’ Tim Is the Best Reissue of 2023
In this episode of The Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics talk about the revelatory new version of the beloved rock band’s 1985 LP. Plus, Replacements bassist Tommy Stinson reveals his perfect-10 album.
By Pitchfork
Breaking Down Bad Bunny’s New Album and the Future of Puerto Rican Rap and Reggaeton
In this episode of The Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics dissect Bad Bunny’s latest and highlight a few new queer artists from Puerto Rico who are taking the island’s music to exciting new places.
By Pitchfork
Debating the Best Songs of 2023, Part Two
In this episode of the Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics battle it out over some of their favorite songs of the year, by artists including Troye Sivan, Kendrick Lamar, Big Thief and more. Plus: Devendra Banhart tells us all about his dream collaboration.
By Pitchfork
Debating the Best Songs of 2023, Part One
In this episode of the Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics take sides and discuss which tracks by some of 2023’s most exciting artists deserve a spot on our upcoming year-end lists.
By Pitchfork
The Good, the Bad, and the Swiftie of Taylor’s Eras Tour Concert Film
In this episode of The Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics wade through the ups and downs of the pop superstar’s new record-breaking live movie.
By Pitchfork
What Drake Is Doing Wrong—and How He Can Fix It
In this episode of the Pitchfork Review podcast, our critics talk about what made them care about Drake in the first place, why his new album For All the Dogs is so frustratingly mid, and what he should do next.
By Pitchfork
articles.author: Condé Nast

articles.title: Music Articles & Features
articles.content:
---
title: Music Articles & Features
author: Condé Nast
url: https://pitchfork.com/features/
hostname: pitchfork.com
description: Longform and in-depth analysis about the most exciting and important music being released today
sitename: Pitchfork
date: 2025-08-14
tags: ['web']
---
Dekmantel Is a Dance Festival Shedding Light on the Underground
We touched down in Amsterdam for the 2025 edition of the left-of-center electronic festival and came back with some thoughts about live sets, drum heads, speaker cabinets, bass fiends, techno lords, and the simple power of naming some club-ready bangers.
By Jeremy D. Larson
The 59 Best Albums of 2025 So Far
By Madison Bloom, Nina Corcoran, Anna Gaca, Walden Green, Jeremy D. Larson, Marissa Lorusso, and Philip Sherburne
Night Out 2025: Pitchfork and Them’s Showcase for the Future of Queer Music
By Olivier LafontantPhotography by Dillon Edlin
The 37 Most Anticipated Albums of Summer 2025
By Madison Bloom, Nina Corcoran, Walden Green, Jazz Monroe, Matthew Strauss, and Eric Torres
The 50 Most Anticipated Albums of Spring 2025
By Madison Bloom, Nina Corcoran, Walden Green, Jazz Monroe, and Matthew Strauss
What Happened at Pitchfork’s Bladee Zine Launch
By PitchforkPhotography by Caroline Friedman
A Rare Interview With Bladee, the Mystic Oracle of Internet Rap
By Meaghan GarveyPhotography by Jason Nocito
Highlights From Pitchfork’s 2024 Year in Music Club Night
By PitchforkPhotography by Sam Wachs
Highlights From Pitchfork and Thought Enthusiast’s Year in Music Panel
By PitchforkPhotography by Sam Wachs
The 50 Best Albums of 2024 So Far
By Anna Gaca, Isabelia Herrera, Jeremy D. Larson, and Philip Sherburne
The 18 Best Moments From Pitchfork Music Festival 2024
By Boutayna Chokrane, Nina Corcoran, and Heven Haile
The 41 Most Anticipated Albums of Summer 2024
By Boutayna Chokrane, Nina Corcoran, Jazz Monroe, Matthew Strauss, and Eric Torres
The 50 Most Anticipated Albums of Spring 2024
By Madison Bloom, Boutayna Chokrane, Nina Corcoran, Matthew Strauss, and Eric Torres
How Waxahatchee Made the Album of Her (Second) Life
By Andy CushPhotography by Bobby Doherty
Chasing the Goblin With Mabe Fratti, the Guatemalan Cellist at the Heart of Mexico City’s Avant-Rock Scene
By Philip SherburnePhotography by Filip Preis
